Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Liquefied Gas Electrolytes for High Energy Density Energy Storage Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
This STTR Phase I project is focused on improving the energy density, safety and ultra-low temperature capability of battery devices. Conventional batteries fall short of these critical requirements for next-generation electric vehicle technologies, which are necessary to reduce emissions and the nation?s reliance on fossil fuel imports. Although the eventual goal of the proposed technology is to enter automotive markets, it may have an equally strong impact for applications in other areas requiring energy storage at low-temperatures. For example, multiple efforts aim to enable high-atmosphere telecommunications to further global connectivity to the internet, particularly in remote locations of the globe in third world countries whose standard of living could be enhanced with greater communication and education. Further, the proposed chemistry could also potentially be useful in electrochemical deposition of difficult to plate metals such as titanium or silicon for use in the aerospace, medical or high tech industries, areas which will ensure the U.S. remains internationally competitive while increasing job opportunity and tax revenue from emerging technologies. It is also a priority of this STTR to coordinate with the partner research institution to providing training and internship opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented communities in this research work to further improve our national industry by training the next generation workforce to better be prepared for industry and higher-education.

This project aims to develop a novel electrolyte chemistry for next generation energy storage devices which has potential to address these three critical areas (energy density, safety, wide temperature operation). While conventional electrolyte chemistry commonly uses solvent solutions which are typically liquid at room temperature, this project will explore the use of solvent solutions which are gaseous at room temperature and liquefied under moderate pressures. Preliminary work on this novel electrolyte chemistry has shown high performance at ultra-low temperatures, enabling many high-atmosphere and aerospace applications without need for additional thermal management and engineering. In addition, a reversible battery shut-down mechanism at high temperatures, inherent in the electrolyte chemistry, allow for strong mitigation of thermal runaway for improved battery safety. Finally, high potential for a substantial increase in energy density with use of next-generation electrode materials has been shown to be possible. The focus of this project will be to develop these novel electrolytes and demonstrate superior performance in a full cell device with application to the automotive industry and low-temperature markets. The underlying fundamental chemistry with these new materials is a relatively new field and it is hoped these materials will lead to advances in next-generation energy storage devices and other technologies, leading to new industries, job growth and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is currently a global effort to electrify transportation and increase renewable energy production, much of which is critically dependent on the increased deployment of battery devices. The Li-ion battery was originally developed with a focus on smaller consumer electronics (ex., laptops, cell phones). While their use in electric vehicles and grid storage is growing, it is generally agreed that a breakthrough battery technology is needed for wider adoption into these critical markets. Such a technology must lower the cost of batteries while increasing their energy content, improve safety, function across various climates, and preferably work with current manufacturing techniques, materials, and supply chains.

It is generally accepted the bottle neck to the development of a next generation battery chemistry is the electrolyte within the cell. Conventional batteries use a liquid electrolyte while solid-state electrolytes are being heavily researched to potentially improve on battery performance. South 8 Technologies is the first to develop and work to commercialize a novel class of gaseous solvents which may be liquefied under moderate pressures to use in Liquefied Gas Electrolytes. These electrolyte show potential to increase energy, lower cost, improve safety, and with excellent temperature performance.

Through this NSF STTR Phase I, various Liquefied Gas Electrolytes were explored for use with the lithium metal anode which has the highest energy of all anodes. Notable improvements were made on the lithium metal anode including very high coulombic efficiencies over hundreds of cycles with very dense metal deposition. Further, this performance continues to exceptionally low temperatures as low as -60 °C. Performance was also measured on conventional cathodes (NMC) up to 4.5 V vs. Li showing high performance with good capacity retention. The high compatibility with both the Li metal anode and NMC cathodes potentially may enable cell energy per mass increase by 80%.

To demonstrate these electrolytes, although under pressure, may still be used in conventional cylindrical form-factors, 18650 cylindrical cells were procured from partners, filled with our electrolyte and sealed with a proprietary cap design. It was shown that the cells hold pressure very well over a wide range of temperatures from +60 °C down to -80 °C. This demonstration allows for South 8 Technologies to pursue partners that may be otherwise unwilling to alter their manufacturing practices.

Improved safety performance was also demonstrated via a unique high temperature shut down of the electrolyte. At increased temperatures, the salt within the Liquefied Gas Electrolyte will naturally precipitate out of solution, causing the electrolyte conductivity to decrease to near zero. When the temperature is cooled, the salt naturally solubilizes back into solution and conductivity is restored. This effect was demonstrated in a cylindrical cell and impedance was shown to increase by a factor of x36 when the temperature reached +60 C, effectively shutting down cell operation. Future efforts will include increasing this shut down temperature to closer to +80 C. This electrolyte shut down effectively prevents any thermal runaway reactions from occurring due to near-zero ionic mobility in the electrolyte.

Though early in development, the Liquefied Gas Electrolyte chemistry has shown high potential for improved cell energy, temperature performance, and safety while utilizing common materials and manufacturing methods. This NSF STTR Phase I enabled much of this work which has allows us to engage with several of these customers. While our beach-head market may likely include the low temperature space (aerospace, arctic, etc.) due to the low volume and high cost, South 8’s eventual aim is to pursue larger grid storage and automotive markets.
